Streetlight

written byErnest Brawley

Published by Barringer Publishing/Schlesinger Advertising - 2/1/2022

This novel takes place in New York City, during the 1970s, when crime and drugs ruled the streets. Much of its action occurs in a renowned drug rehab center called "Streetlight." Run by a famous and respected former addict, Al Rakozi, the facility is praised by newspapers and politicians in the city, yet within its walls hide shocking secrets. Shelley Friedman is a reporter seeking the truth about Streetlight and its narcissistic leader, at considerable risk. e story peaks when Shelley's lover, Jim Range, pretends to be a drug addict and joins Streetlight to expose it as a criminal enterprise, much to both his peril and demise.

The Alamo Tree

written byErnest Brawley

Published by Simon & Schuster - 1/1/1984

Traces the stories of the Carrizos, a Mexican family who rise from servants to financial giants, and the O'Hares, an American family who develop a small hotel into an internationally famous resort

Tyson

written byErnest Cashmore

Published by Polity - 1/14/2005

Beast. Monster. Savage. Psycho. The glowering menace of Mike Tyson has spooked us for almost two decades. And still we remain fascinated. Why? Ellis Cashmoreâ²s answer is disturbing: white society has created Tyson as vengeance for the loss of privilege produced by civil rights. Cashmoreâ²s eviscerating analysis of Tysonâ²s life and the culture in which he grew up, rose to prominence and descended into disgrace provokes the reader into reâthinking the role of one of the most controversial and infamous figures of recent history. Told as an odysseyâstyle homeward journey to Tysonâ²s multiâpathological origins in the raciallyâexplosive ghettos of the 1960s, Tysonâ²s story is part biography, part tragedy and part exposition. His associations with people like Al Sharpton, Don King and Tupac Shakur shaped his life; and events, such as the O J Simpson trial and the Rodney King riots, formed a turbulent background for the Tyson psychodrama. Over the course of an epic boxing career, Tyson was transformed from the most celebrated athlete on earth to a primal, malevolent hateâfigure. Yet, even after being condemned as a brute, Tyson retained a power â a power to captivate. Cashmore reveals that the sources of that power lie as much in us as in Tyson himself.

Did you know that the movie Fast-Walking is based on the book The Rap?

A corrupt prison guard becomes involved in a plot to murder a black revolutionary serving time in his prison.
